TopicTitle: Smallest Stock Single Stage To Solar Escape

Articles.Content:
Escaping from Kerbin\'s gravity well is easy. From Kerbol\'s, not so much. All stock parts, except for decouplers are allowed. Retuning SAS/ASAS Kp, Ki, and Kd values is permissible, but changes must be listed. Fewest parts and lowest liftoff weight are the goals. Bonus points for higher velocities after final burn, and/or leaving Kerbin\'s SOI. Additional bonus points for clever maneuvers.

Interestingly, this can be done without any slingshots, as my attempt shows:

The SSSTSE consists of 95 LFTs, 18 LV-T30s, 1 LV-T45, 18 Struts, 1 ASAS (untuned), 1 Command module. 134 parts, for a GLOW of 278.2

Initial launch was into the lowest parking orbit possible.

Escape burn was performed at approximately local midnight.
With stock parts, it\'s easier to do this single stage than it is multi-stage...
Wouldn\'t a stock multistage be able to use less than half as many parts as I used?

Wouldn\'t a stock multistage be able to use less than half as many parts as I used?

Considering stock engines and decouplers are incredibly heavy, I\'m not too sure.

This is actually getting towards the high end of what a single stock stage is capable of, since lift-off is required; it\'s quite likely this would be easier with a two-stage, though three stage would be excessive.

Considering stock engines and decouplers are incredibly heavy, I\'m not too sure.

This challenge should be working towards the outer edge of a single stage\'s ?V, with gravity and aerodynamic drag being serious issues. That stock fuel tanks can now be mounted on radial decouplers (or with radial skin to skin connections), also does a lot to alleviate the staging penalties.
